results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Paul Tortelier, the French cellist and composer, conducts a master-class of four members of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain and instructs them in some of the finer points in the Dvorak Cell Concerto. Tortelier gives a history of cello playing and the film ends with an excerpt from the great Cello Concerto by Lalo.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group

results.title: The Bassoon
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Education Foundation for Visual Arts and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
The history and technique of the bassoon are explained by Archie Camden, one of the world’s most renowned players of the bassoon. He explains the complex fingering, and demonstrates intonation, staccato playing and trills. Ends with Camden’s famous arrangement of ‘Allegro Spiritoso’ by Senaille.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Education Foundation for Visual Arts and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: Time to talk
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”
Discusses the importance of the parents’ role in teaching their children to explore the world through talking, relating and feeling.

results.title: Talking shop: demands on language
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Australia. Dept. of Education and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
A teenage boy and girl, when interviewed for vacation jobs in a store, reveal a limited capacity to express themselves. Describes their feelings about their jobs, their fellow workers and shows how they adapted to the situation. Useful for linguistics studies and career advisers. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels and tertiary teacher education.

results.title: Reading for meaning: the Goodman Model
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch your language”
Understanding the reading process. Professors Ken and Yetta Goodman discuss the problems of the teaching of reading with a class of teachers in Australia. Docments some of their main propositions relating to language in use, miscue analysis and reading. Stresses the need to focus on the strengths of children and not simply the weaknesses.
Suitable for teacher level.

results.title: Language at twelve (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
Intended primarily to emphasise the diversity and complexity of language in the life of a 12-year-old. This film focuses on two 12-year-olds who are involved in a school language project. Shows their interaction with a sufficient number of significant people in their lives for us to gain an impression of how the demands upon their speech shift. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Eastern victory
results.creator_credit: Philip Dorte, John Elliot and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “War in the Air”.
The three further phases of the air war in the Far East (1943-45). First, the air campaign in Burma. Second, the Pacific air actions leading to the bombing of Tokyo; the third, the atomic bomb, the surrender of Japan, and the resumption of air traffic in the Far East.
